logo_css.title: Logo Style
logo_css.description:
Modify the styles below to adjust your logo.

Logo CSS

The logo CSS stylesheet allows you to adjust the size, and space around your logo. We use em as sizing unit by default, because it is relative to the font-size, but you can also use px. You can use decimals in em values, for example 2.5em.

Font Size

If you are using a text-logo, you can change logo size by adjusting the font-size.

font-size: 2em;

Padding

Add space around your logo by applying padding.

padding: 1em 0;

* The 0 in the above indicates that we don't want padding on left- and right.

Margin Top

Add additional space above your logo with margin-top.

margin-top: 0em;

Width

If you are using an image-logo, you can use width to limit the size.

width: 300px;

TIP: Sidebar

When using sidebar layout, it is better to remove the padding and apply a margin.

padding: 0 0;
margin-top: 1em;

items.inlinetitle:
Show X3 Styler

Show X3 Styler Panel

This setting toggles your X3 styler panel, which is used to view different combinations of skins, colors, layouts and fonts. You would normally keep this setting enabled while adjusting your website, and disable it once your website design is ready.

Enabled
The styler button can be found in the bottom right corner of your website, and allows you to open the X3 styler panel. You can also force the styler panel to automatically open by appending ?styler to your website url.

* Browser will remember the current state of your styler panel.

Disabled
The styler panel will be disabled and entirely inaccessible.

items.title: Layout

Select Layout

Select Layout

Select the main layout for your X3 website.

* Preview all layouts from the styler interface.

Fixed Topbar Menu

Fixed Topbar

Use this option to fix the topbar-menu to top of screen on scroll.

Fixed

Attaches the menu to top of screen on scroll.

Fixed on scroll up

Attaches the menu to top of screen on scroll up. This is recommended, and will only show the fixed menu on scroll-up, which indicates the visitor may want to navigate.

* Fixed topbar settings only apply for the topbar layouts.

items.inlinetitle:
Wide Topbar

Wide Topbar

By default, the entire topbar section is limited within an 1140 px width. This makes sure the logo and menu remain within a functional viewing area also on large screens. Enable the wide setting if you for some reason want to stretch the topbar to 100% width of screen, regardless of screen size.

* When using wide, you should also apply the filled skin style.

items.title:
Slide Style

Slidemenu Slide Style

Decides how the slidemenu displays.

Overlay
The slidemenu will overlay the website. When links are clicked, the slidemenu will remain in view.

Push
Pushes the entire website to the left when slidemenu opens. When links are clicked, the slidemenu will close before the link opens.

* Push will ALWAYS apply for mobile devices and small screens.
Skin

Select Skin

Select Skin

Select a skin for your X3 website. Skins are complex color schemes, which alongside fonts, sets the mood of your X3 website.

* Preview all skins from the styler interface.

Primary Color [empty = skin default]

Primary Color

The primary color sets a complimentary color to go with your skin, and is used for several page elements. The color you pick here should depend on which skin you have selected. Normally, you should select a relatively strong color.

If left blank, the specific skins default primary color will be used. You can apply any color name like darkorange, or use a hex-based color like #FFC000.

* We recommend using color names found in the skin selector from your styler interface.

Navigation Background

Navigation Background

Using filled navigation will set a soft background color behind the topbar, sidebar and footer. Use clear for a transparent background on these items.
Font

Select Font Combo

Select Font Combo

Choose from a variety of font combinations, available to preview from the X3 Styler.

Source

You can edit the font source or completely replace it with your own custom string.

Disable Google Fonts

If you want to disable Google fonts, select the none value. Font will default to Helvetica Neue, and you can instead set your own font-family from custom CSS.

Logo Title

Logo title

Add your logo title text.

Logo title when using IMAGE

When using an image logo, the title will apply as alt attribute for the image. The alt attribute is an alternative text for your image logo, invisible to visitors, but often used by search engines.

* You should always include a short logo title that represents your website.

items.inlinetitle:
Logo Effects

Logo Effects

When enabled, your text-logo will animate on mouse hover, for a playful visual effect. You can include as many words as you like in the title, and each word will animate separately.

* The Interactive 3D logo-effect comes as is, and cannot easily be customized.

Synchronize Effects

Synchronize Logo Effects

With this setting enabled, all words in the title will synchronize to the same animation. This tends to make the resulting effect more visually composed. When this setting is disabled, all words in the title will animate separately, for a more random effect.

* This setting has no effect if your title contains only a single word.
* If you have more than two words in your logo, we recommend keeping this setting enabled.

Logo Link

Enabled

Popup Enabled

If you disable the popup, clicking on an image will instead navigate the visitor to a separate image landing-page. This represents a less functional interface for browsing images.

Auto Open

Popup Auto Open

If enabled, first image in gallery will immediately open and display in popup after page load.

* Auto-open can be applied on a per-gallery basis from page settings › gallery › popup.

items.title:
Image Click

Image Click Behavior

Decides behavior of the popup when current image in popup is clicked.

prev | next
If mouse cursor is located on right half of image, click will proceed to next image. If mouse cursor is located on left half of image, click will proceed to previous image.

next
Clicking image will proceed to next image.

zoom
Clicking image will zoom the current image, if the image is zoomable.

* Click behavior does not apply for mobile devices, since primary navigation is swipe.

items.inlinetitle:
Zoom Button

Show Zoom Button

Show the zoom button, which allows the visitor to zoom the image to original size.

* The zoom button is only visible if the image can be scaled up without exceeding original dimensions.

Share Button

Show Share Button

Show the share button, which allows visitors to share the image on social services.

* Services in the share button are inherited from the toolbar settings.

Transitions

Transitions

Includes an animated slide effect when navigating between images in the popup.

* Transitions do not apply for touch devices, where it is natural to instead swipe between images. Also, for technical reasons, the transition does not apply in the loop stitch between the last and first image.

History

Popup History

Adds a #hashtag in the browser URL with the current image ID. This allows you to deep link to the image when directly sharing the URL.

items.inlinetitle:
Collapse Toolbar

Collapse Toolbar

Toolbar will show in minimized mode, until visitor moves mouse over the share button, in which case the toolbar will expand to show all items.

This setting is recommended, to keep the user interface clean until the visitor chooses to interact with the toolbar.

Autohide Toolbar

Autohide Toolbar

Autohides the toolbar after a few seconds of mouse inactivity.

Show labels on mouse hover

Show labels on mouse hover

Shows the toolbar text labels on mouse hover.

Show popup on click

Show popup on share-button click

When the main share-button is clicked, a popup window will open to display all sharing options.

Use 3D effect

Use 3D effect

When enabled, the sharing popup window will use an interactive 3D effect on mouse move.

Use AddThis

Use AddThis

When enabled, the toolbar will use third-party sharing service AddThis.

* We recommend keeping this disabled.

Enable for mobile devices [Recommended Off]

Enable toolbar for mobile devices

Enable the toolbar for mobile touch devices.

By default, the toolbar is disabled for mobile devices. This is because mobile browsers usually have built-in sharing mechanisms, which interact directly with native applications like Facebook, Twitter, Google etc. Most mobile users have applications installed for their social services, so why try to share a page from a browser-window which requires them to log in? Also, since mobile screens are small, it is a good idea to keep the interface clean.

items.title:
Vertical offset [px]

Toolbar vertical offset

Set the vertical offset position for the toolbar relative to top of screen. We recommend keeping this at 65px, which keeps it in relative good view, without interfering too much with other potential page elements.

You can also use a negative value to offset the toolbar from bottom of screen, but this will only work properly if you have disabled "Collapse Toolbar".

Screen align

Toiolbar screen align

Decide which side of the screen the toolbar will align to.

When set to "auto", the toolbar will always align to left, except when using the left-sidebar, in which case the toolbar will align to right.
Items

items.description:
Add-, remove- or change toolbar items.

Toolbar Items

The toolbar items are intended for social sharing, but can also be used for custom links or custom content opened in the X3 popup window. Select items to display, create new items, or change the order. You can set your own labels, colors and icons from Font-Awesome.

JSON Configuration

The items configuration is a JSON object, and must be syntactically correct. If you get a red warning in the left margin, it means there is something wrong and the config will be corrupted. Be sure to wrap all "keys" and "values" inside double-quotes, and all items (except the last), should be followed by a comma.

Item

"id" : "facebook"
ID is just an identifier for the item, and has no function except for some special built-in items like the main share button, email, comments and download. ID must always be populated.

"icon" : "facebook"
Select any icon to use from Font-Awesome.

"label" : "Share on Facebook"
The text to display on item mouse hover, in the overlay-popup and in the X3 popup.

"url" : "https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=%7B%7Burl%7D%7D"
URL for the item. Can be a social sharing endpoint, which requires using one or more of the sharing variables %7B%7Burl%7D%7D %7B%7Btext%7D%7D, or can be a plain link to another web page or a popup.

"color" : "#3b5998"
Set the color for the icon. This setting is not required for the default items already included, as they are hardcoded into the X3 stylesheet. Only use this for new links and services, or if you want to override a color.

"display" : "page|overlay|popup"
Optional setting to only show the item in one or more modes: page, overlay or popup. Useful for creating items that only display in specific modes. Ignore this setting, or leave empty if you want the item to display in all modes. You can add multiple items: for example display:'page|overlay' will the popup.

"target" : "window"
Sets the target for the item click. By default, target is set to 'window', which opens a plain browser popup window, necessary for sharing services. However, you can open custom links or even custom content directly in the beautiful native X3 popup window. Additionally, you can simply open links in _blank or _self browser window.

"content" : "<h2>Lorem Ipsum</h2><p>Pellentesque euismod.</p>"
Instead of assigning an URL, you can add content directly in the items content setting. This setting forces target:'popup', and will display the data from content directly in the popup window.

"popup_class" : "some-custom-class"
Custom wrapper class for the native X3 popup window when using target:'popup'. This is an advanced setting for those who want to assign a custom CSS class to style your own content inside the native X3 popup window.

Share URL Variables

If you are adding a new sharing service link, you will first need to locate the specific services endpoint. After slight modification, you can then add the sharing endpoint to your items URL setting.

{{url}} - Encoded url to current page
{{text}} - Title of page
{{description}} - Description of page
{{image_url}} - Encoded image url
{{raw_image_url}} - Raw image url
{{path}} - Relative path to current folder
{{file_name}} - File name without extension
{{file_name_ext}} - File name with extension

For example, Twitter's sharing endpoint looks like this:
https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=TEXT_TO_TWEET&url=URL_TO_SHARE

Therefore, the URL to be added for the twitter item should look like this:
url:"https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text={{text}}&url={{url}}"

items.helpvalue: Page Defaults

Here you can modify default page layout settings, which otherwise are applied separately for each page. The advantage of setting page defaults, is that you don't need to apply settings for each page, unless you specifically want to override some defaults.

items.title: Page

items.helpvalue: Default page details, normally applied separately for each page.

items.title:
Default Page Title * recommended empty

Default Page Title

Add a default title that will apply for all pages until overridden from page settings. We recommend keeping this field empty, since it is bad practice to have duplicate titles for multiple pages. Instead, you should add unique titles for each page, unless the folder name contains a sufficient title.

* Title should contain a brief summary, maximum 60 characters.

Default Page Description * recommended empty

Default Page Description

Add a default description that will apply for all pages until overridden from page settings. We recommend keeping this field empty, since it is bad practice to have duplicate descriptions for multiple pages. Instead, you should add unique descriptions to each page.

* Descriptions should contain a brief summary, maximum 160 characters.

Default Page Date

Default Page Date

Date is only used for pages where you are displaying the date in the page context, for example blog-like pages. Normally, you will set date specifically for each page where you want to display the date, so this is only a default fallback. If you leave default date empty, it will use the page 'updated' date, unless you set a date specifically for the page.

Format

Although you can add the date as you like, we recommend the standardized format YYYY-MM-DD, year-month-day in numerals. The date format may display differently in your website, depending on your settings in global Settings › Advanced › Date Format.

Default body classes [tags]

Default Body Classes

Here you can add default body CSS classes for your page. You can add custom classes (if defined in your custom CSS), or native X3 body classes. For example no-headercustom-class

* Add items by typing them in order, and hitting enter/return or comma on keyboard

Important!

If you populate body classes specifically for a page, classes added here will NOT apply because this setting is only a default. If you want to INCLUDE body classes for each page, you should instead add them to the include › body setting.

menu-absolute,menu-absolute-20,menu-absolute-50,no-footer,no-pad,no-header,hide-toolbar

Page Layout Items [tags]

Page Layout Items

This setting is used to set the default order of page items. Normally, you should keep the default settings here, and instead edit on a per-page basis if required.

* Add items by typing them in order, and hitting enter/return or comma on keyboard

Layout Items

There are three page layouts:

context

The context layout contains all page context, which may include title, description, date, amount and content.

folders

The folders layout will display all subfolders (albums) of the current page. If the current page does not have subfolders, folders will not display.

gallery

The gallery layout will display all images of the current page. If the current page does not have any images, the gallery will not display.

NB! folders layout will only display on the page if the page contains subfolders, and gallery layout will only display on page if the page contains images. Therefore, it is very unlikely that you will need to remove them.

Examples

By default, context will display first, followed by page folders, and gallery. Normally, you won't have both folders and images in the same page.contextfoldersgallery

In some cases, you may wish to switch the order of page items. In the below example, gallery displays before the page context.gallerycontextfolders

If you remove the gallery, it will not display in the page, even if the page has images.contextfolders

context,folders,gallery

Default Layout Width

Default Layout Width

This option sets the default layout width for all items displaying in the page.

NB! Layout width options are responsive, and are relative to the device screen width. For example on small mobile devices, this option has no effect, because the layout will scale down to device max width anyway. This option mainly affects desktop-sized screens, where the layout may need to be contained inside a functional viewing area.

Wide

The wide option sets the layout to display at 100% screen width. It can be useful for many folders- and gallery layouts (especially slideshow), but should not be used for context.

Default

This is the default option, where the layout is wrapped inside a default 1140 px maximum width. This ensures that page content remains within functional viewing areas also on very large screens.

Narrow

This option sets a relatively narrow layout, which is often suitable for context (text). Text content should be limited by width, because optimal human reading is limited to 50-80 characters per line (like a book).

Narrower

This option sets a narrower layout, which is very functional for context (text). This is the default width for the context layout.

Narrowest

This option sets a very narrow layout, which is suitable for very specific content, for example a contact form.

Default Layout CSS Classes [tags]

Layout CSS Classes

Layout classes are CSS classes that can be applied to all layout items in your page. You can add native X3 classes here, or custom CSS classes.

Example

separator add a horizontal rule below all layout items (except the last), to clearly separate the items visually.

Default settings for the page context layout.

Context Layout

What is the page context layout?

The context layout is part of the page that displays page details, including title, description and content. The context will normally display at the top of the page, before any folders and/or galleries.

In addition to the three default items, context can also include additional items labelamountfolders_amountdate and preview

items.inlinetitle:
Hide Context

Hide Context

Use this option to hide the page context. It is highly unlikely that you would want to apply this setting as a default, as that means all your pages context will be hidden.

items.title:
Default Items [tags]

Default Context Items

This setting is used to set default items of the context layout, and in which order they display. You will normally keep default settings here, and instead edit items on a per-page basis when required. The following items are available: titlelabelamountfolders_amountdatepreviewdescriptioncontent

* Add items by typing them in order, and hitting enter/return or comma on keyboard

Items

title displays the title of the page, normally included first.

label Instead of displaying the page title, you can use the label for shorter titles. This requires populating the label field for pages obviously.

amount displays the amount of images in the page gallery, useful for gallery pages. * Will not display if the page has no images.

folders_amount displays the amount of subfolders in the page. * Will not display if the page has no subfolders.

date displays the page date, useful for blog-like pages.

preview displays the page preview image, useful for blog-like pages when you want to display a related image below the title.

description Displays the page short description, normally included below the title.

content displays the main page content, normally included below title and description. * Content will only display if the page has content.

Examples

Default context items.titledescriptioncontent

Blog-like page with preview-image and date example.titledatedescriptionpreviewcontent

Alternative gallery-page, showing images-amount and excluding description.titleamount

title,label,amount,folders_amount,date,preview,description,content

Default Width

Default Context Width

This option sets the default width for the context layout. Normally, you will keep this option to the default narrower for context, as it keeps text-content within a functional reading-width.

NB! Layout width options are responsive, and are relative to the device screen width. For example on small mobile devices, this option has no effect, because the layout will scale down to device max width anyway. This option mainly affects desktop-sized screens, where the layout may need to be contained inside a functional viewing area.

Wide

The wide option sets the layout to display at 100% screen width. It can be useful for many folders and gallery layouts (especially slideshow), but should not be used for context.

Default

This is the default option, where the layout is wrapped inside a default 1140 px maximum width. This ensures that layout remains within functional viewing areas also on very large screens.

Narrow

This option sets a relatively narrow layout, which is often suitable for context (text). Text content should be limited by width, because optimal human reading is limited to 50-80 characters per line (like a book).

Narrower

This option sets a narrower layout, which is very functional for context (text). This is the default width for the context layout.

Narrowest

This option sets a very narrow layout, which is suitable for very specific content, for example a contact form.

Text Align

Text Align

Default text align for the context layout, which includes main content.

left
All text is aligned left.

left / header center * default
Text is aligned left, while main header is aligned center.

left / all headers center
Text is aligned left, while all headers are aligned center.

center
All text is aligned center.
* Use only under special circumstances. Paragraph text should normally always be aligned left!

Default CSS Classes [tags]

Default Context Classes

Context classes are CSS classes that can be applied specifically to the context layout of your page. You can add native X3 classes or custom CSS classes.

* Add classes by typing them in order, and hitting enter/return or comma on keyboard

Important!

If you populate context classes specifically for a page, classes added here will NOT apply because this setting is only a default. If you want to INCLUDE context classes for each page, you should instead add them to the include › context setting.

Aspect ratio

items.title: Folders [layout]

items.helpvalue:
Default settings for the page folders layout.

Folders Layout

What is the page folders layout?

The folders layout is part of the page that shows the page subfolders. This would often be used for an albums or blog page, in both cases listing child pages of the current page.

The folders layout will normally display with preview images from the child folders in a grid layout. However, there are numerous ways to change the layout and style of the folders layout.

items.inlinetitle:
Hide Folders

Hide Folders

Use this setting to hide folders from displaying in the page. PS! Folders layout will in any case only display if the page has child pages.

items.helpvalue: Layout

items.title:
Default Folders Layout

Default Folders Layout

Select a default layout for the folders layout. Although this can be set specifically for each page, you can set a default here.

Grid

Use the grid method to create robust grid layouts, which respond nicely to different screen widths.

Vertical

Simply list images vertically in a blog-like style. Functional, responsive and works nicely on all devices.

Justified

Use the justified method to create neat layouts with images of different aspects. Justified will scale images within rows to allow an elegant layout which the fills space available.

Columns

Use the columns method to create a vertical masonry-style layout which emphasizes portrait aspect images. Columns will scale images within columns to allow an elegant layout which fills space available.

Carousel

The carousel method displays multiple items in a horizontal carousel layout. The carousel is useful for teaser pages.
Vertical

items.helpvalue:
Default Vertical Layout options.

Vertical Layout

The vertical method creates a layout where images are simply stacked vertically and respond to screen width. This layout is simple but effective for scrolling through items both on desktop- and small touchscreen devices. It is recommended to use the vertical layout with the narrow layout width.

items.inlinetitle:
Scrollnav

Scrollnav

Adds controls on the right side of the screen to elegantly scroll through images with mouse click or keyboard click.

Horizontal Rule

Horizontal Rule

Adds a subtle 1px horizontal rule between each folder item. An elegant way to clearly separate items.

items.title: Grid

items.helpvalue:
Default Grid Layout options.

Grid Layout

Robust grid layout, which reponds to different screen widths. Because it is a symmetrical grid, unless your images are all the same aspect, you should use the crop setting to achieve a uniform layout.

items.title:
Columns Amount [large, medium, small screen size]

Grid Columns

* This setting only applies if use width is disabled.

Create a grid layout by defining the amount of columns available in the grid on large-, medium- and small screens respectively.

* Add items by typing them in order, and hitting enter/return or comma on keyboard

Examples

The default grid displays 3 columns on large screens, 2 columns on small screens and a single column on small (mobile) screens.321

Add more columns to create a thumbnails-like layout. In this example, we have 6 columns on large screens, 3 columns on medium screens, and 1 column on small screens. * We recommend a single column on small screens (mobile devices), because it simply works best.631

By omitting values for medium- and small screens, you can set an amount of columns that apply for all screen sizes. Keep in mind, when doing such, your grid will scale down to a large degree on small devices.3

Column Width [px]

Column Width

* This setting only applies if use width is enabled.

Instead of defining the amount of columns, set a target-width for columns. The amount of columns created, will depend on the target-width and the available horizontal space. * When using Column-width, the layout is responsive by nature, because less columns at any specific width will fit in smaller screens.

items.inlinetitle:
Use Width by default

Grid Use Width

There are two ways of using the grid layout.

Use Width Disabled

By default, use-width is disabled, and the grid-layout relies on the columns setting to define a columns layout.

Use Width Enabled

If use-width is enabled, grid columns will attempt to occupy the width defined in the column width setting. The amount of columns you get, will therefore depend on the target-width, and the width of the parent container.

items.title:
Grid Space[px, -1 for auto]

Grid Space

The amount of space in px between grid items.
Justified

items.helpvalue:
Default Justified Layout options.

It is recommended to disable the audio player for small mobile devices (smartphones).

Why is this recommended?

  • Audio player will hog bandwidth, which is significant if the user is not on wifi.
  • Audio player will drain battery power.
  • Audio quality is relatively poor and may not reflect beneficially for your website.
  • Unlikely that visitors will want to play audio from their smartphone.
  • Audioplayer button crowds the user interface on small screens.

* Audioplayer will still display on large phones (typically iPhone 6 plus) and tablets.

Autoplay * see restrictions in help

Audio autoplay

Attempt to autoplay audio on page-load.

About autoplay

There are several conditions that come into play when attempting to autoplay audio, including mobile restrictions, browser restrictions, stored play state and browser window focus.

Visitor's previous play state

If X3 detects that the visitor has already interacted with the audioplayer (clicked to play or stop audio), the visitor's last play state will be given priority before the autoplay setting. For example, if the visitor has STOPPED the audio on previous visit, audio will NOT attempt to autoplay. If the visitor was PLAYING audio on previous visit, audio will attempt to autoplay (even if autoplay option is disabled). If visitor has not yet interacted with the audioplayer button (all new visitors), the autoplay setting will be used.

Autoplay browser restrictions

All mobile browsers and some desktop browsers (notably Chrome and Safari) will block audio autoplay [read more], until the visitor interacts with the website by click or touch. For browsers that do not allow immediate autoplay, X3 will autoplay audio after the visitor interacts with the website by click or touch within 1 minute after the website loads.

Browser window focus

Autoplay requires that the website's browser tab is in focus when the website loads. If the visitor is viewing a different website/tab, they would not want audio to autoplay from a background tab. Similar to above, X3 will instead autoplay audio after the visitor interacts with the website within 1 minute after the website loads.

Mobile autoplay

Audio will only autoplay on mobile devices if the visitor has previously interacted with the audioplayer and left it in PLAY state. Even then, because of mobile browser restrictions, autoplay will only be able to trigger once the visitor interacts with the website by touch. Autoplay on mobile devices is a bad idea, because mobile visitors don't expect audio to blast from their device just because they touch the screen, and not to mention unexpected bandwidth usage and poor sound quality. If they really want audio, they will click the play button.

Video Intro Plugin

The video-background plugin allows you to use a video as page background. This plugin can be useful on your home page, or to emphasize certain special pages. To add a video-background to any page, simply upload an mp4 video file, and set the video source.

[see demo]

Limitations

  • Autoplay limitations
    Some visitors may have disabled autoplay in their browser, in which case the video simply won't autoplay. Furthermore, many old mobile devices simply don't allow autoplay. To allow mobile devices to autoplay video, you must have the "muted" setting checked.
  • Video Cropped
    For a background video to display nicely at any height, on any device, on any screen aspect, the video may be cropped appropriately to 'fit' the designated stage area.
  • Does not work for sidebar layout
    Because of the technical difference of the sidebar layout, the video intro plugin currently only works for the topbar- and slidemenu layouts.
  • H.264 encoded mp4 format
    Video in HTML5 is limited by various file formats and codecs. To be sure that your video displays properly across all browsers, the video should be encoded in H.264 codec, in mp4 format [ref].
  • 2MB Upload Limit
    Your host may have a 2MB upload limitation, in which case you would need to upload large video files by FTP into appropriate folders.
  • Browser remembers play-state
    If a visitor clicks to 'pause' the video, the video will also be paused next time the page loads. This is just common sense.
  • Slow internet connection
    If your video file is large, and the visitor is on a relatively slow connection, they may see the video start and stop frequently while buffering.
  • Seamless Loop
    Don't expect the video to loop seamlessly in all browsers. Depending on the browser, it might take several milliseconds before the video re-starts after loop.

Recommendations

The background-video plugin is intended to be used as a motion-background to compliment the page content. Don't use video just because you can or because it looks nice. We recommend using a short, subtle video loop, without sound, lasting only a few seconds, and compressed at acceptable file size.

Panel Database Version

The panel database version offers a few advantages: Create- users, manage users, and edit user profiles directly from the control panel.

* The panel database version does not have anything to do with the X3 frontend.

How to setup panel database version

  1. Create New Database
    Create a new database, typically from your server control panel, or from phpMyAdmin. You can use any database name, for example x3_panel.
  2. Test Connection
    Before saving database settings in the panel, you should verify your database connection with the X3 Database Connection Checker.
  3. Add Database Details
    Add database connection details to panel settings (this page). You will automatically be logged out from the panel after clicking save.
  4. Install Panel DB
    Proceed to the X3 /panel/install/ page, and install the X3 panel database.
  5. Login
    Login to the panel with your new admin credentials set from the install process.
  6. Delete install folder
    If everything works, log in by FTP, and delete the panel/install folder.

Uploader

Upload Resizer

Default settings for resizing images as they are being uploaded. If you disable the upload resizer, original uploaded images will not be resized. This feature is recommended to make sure original images are resized to a web-friendly format, as it is dysfunctional for the website to force 5000px 4MB images.

* Images will often scale down additionally for certain layouts and/or devices, so the resize just sets the maximum 'large' image size.

Manual Resizing

You can disable the upload resizer if you are manually resizing images to a web-friendly format prior to upload from your application of choice. In fact, manual resizing is recommended if you are familiar with the process already, because it offers better quality control. A general web-friendly format for original images, may be between 1280-2000px long side with 85-95 JPG compression, but it all depends on your requirements. For a good balance, we recommend 1600 px long-side, at compression-level 95, for high-quality images at acceptable file-size.

Resize to Width and Height

The resize to width- and height fields, represents the bounding box of what your images will be resized within. For example, a 4752 x 3168 px lanscape-aspect image will resize to width-limit 1600 x 1067, while a 3168 x 4752 portrait-aspect image, will resize to height-limit 1067 x 1600. Original aspect ratios will always be kept intact.

Compression

JPG images are highly compressed with minimal 'loss', which means the quality degrades to a certain degree. However, if you leave a high-quality compression (90-95), you won't normally be able to detect any loss of quality with the naked eye.

items.title:
Auto Image Orientation

Auto Image Orientation

Although most cameras rotate images to the correct orientation as they are taken, some cameras and smartphones do not. Instead, they store the image orientation as a value in the image's EXIF meta data. While desktop applications and cameras are capable of reading this data and displaying the images in correct orientation, web browsers unfortunately are not. Therefore, images that are not physically rotated to the correct orientation, should be corrected on upload.

resizer
The most effective option, is to allow the uploader image resizer to auto-correct orientation before uploading the image. The advantage is that there is no loss of quality while rotating the image, as it is handled in the same process that resizes the image.

* This method requires the resizer to be ENABLED
* Since the upload resizer is browser-based, it cannot write the corrected EXIF value back to the image. This is mostly harmless, as images will display correctly in the website, but if someone downloads the image, the EXIF orientation value will be incorrect.

server
This option will auto-correct image orientation on server after upload, and will also set the correct EXIF rotation meta tag in the image.

* This method involves re-compressing the JPG image as it is rotated on server, incurring a slight quality degradation on the image (mostly unnoticeable).
* This method requires that your server has sufficient memory available to rotate full size images. If this is not the case, you will get an error on upload.

no
No automatic image orientation will occur.

Manual Refresh [Recommended if you have 100+ folders]

Manual Menu Refresh

With this setting is enabled, a new button "REFRESH MENU" will appear in the panel menu, which allows you to manually refresh your X3 website MENU. The advantage of this procedure, is that pages get created faster since the menu is always pre-cached manually.

* When disabled, site menu will get created automatically after any change from panel.

Should I enable this?

You may wish to enable this feature if you have a heavy content structure (100+ folders), and/or if your web server is slow to load pages after you make changes from the panel. Use this feature to refresh your X3 website menu only when you need to.

When should I click 'Refresh Menu'?

If you have this feature enabled, you should click to refresh only after you make changes from the panel that affect the main menu. This could be when you create a new page, change the label of a menu item, or make changes that apply directly to the menu. As a rule of thumb, it is a good idea to always refresh the menu after you are done making changes.

Is it safe to disable this feature?

Normally YES, but it depends on the depth of your content and the speed of your server. If your menu refresh process is slow, it would be a good idea to keep this feature enabled. If your menu refresh process is fast, you could easily disable this feature.

* Manual menu refresh does not affect output speed of already-cached pages.

Simple Menu [Extremely fast but some limitations]

Simple Menu Mode

Simple menu mode will drastically speed up the creation time of your menu. Because of the limitations, this setting is normally unsuitable, but if you have thousands of pages and/or are hosted on a very slow server, it could be a beneficial compromise.

Why so fast?

In simple mode, the menu is created by simply reading the directory structure of your content. Instead of having to load page data for each menu item, it simply creates menu items based on folder names.

Limitations

Simple menu mode has several limitations:

  • Does not support mega menu.
  • Uses folder name instead of label from page settings -> plugins.
  • Does not support special menu settings like links.

* Use this setting if you plan on having thousands of pages and don't require advanced menu behavior. This setting may be especially useful for the sidebar layout.

Disable Menu

Disable Menu

Use this setting to entirely disable your site menu.

Why would I do that?

Normally you won't. It could be useful if you want to entirely ignore the menu-building process until your pages are complete. In some rare cases, you may be creating a single-page website, where the menu is not required.

Force URL

Force URL

Force a specific URL for your X3 website.

Often, you will have multiple URL's that access the same X3 website. Since it is counter-productive to have multiple url's for the same website (read more), we recommend consolidating and redirecting your url's to a single canonical URL of your choice. For example, you may have two or more of the following:

http://domain.com
http://www.domain.com
https://domain.com
https://www.domain.com
http://www.domain.co.uk

For example, if you want URL to always be set to the WWW-version of your website, using SSL (https), you would write: https://www.domain.com

Any request that does NOT match the specified URL, will then redirect appropriately.

Important!

  • Make sure to set a correct URL, else you could end up with an error or infinite redirect loop!
  • Make sure you don't have conflicting redirect rules set elsewhere (in your hosting control panel or htaccess file).
  • Make sure your server supports SSL before attempting to force a https:// url.
  • The force url setting also applies for the X3 control panel.
  • If you are going to change domains or move your X3 website, you should empty this option before proceeding.
  • This setting only applies for requests that are processed by the X3 application. It cannot control or redirect requests that go directly to files or other applications on your server.
  • If you find yourself in a situation where you cannot access the X3 website or control panel because of this setting, you can access by URL /panel/?noredirect to prevent the panel from trying to redirect.

When enabled, image settings (title, description, link etc.) will be saved inside each image as IPTC meta data. The advantage is that images will keep their settings when renaming, moving or copying.

When disabled, all image settings are stored in the folder page.json data file with a reference to the file name. When you rename a file, it will lose it's reference to the settings stored in the page.json file.

* This setting ONLY applies to JPG image files, because it is the only file-type we can write IPTC meta data directly to. All other file types will have their settings stored in the folders page.json data file.
